Some notes

The method of Gaussian elimination actually an algorithmic method to find the inverse of a matrix. This allows us to solve a wider range of systems of equations. When solving a system of equations we stop performing row operations when the augmented matrix of the system has the following properties.

  1. The first non-zero element in each row, called the leading entry, is \(1\).
  2. Each leading entry is in a column to the right of the leading entry in the previous row.
  3. Rows with all zero elements, if any, are below rows having a non-zero element.
  4. The leading entry in each row is the only non-zero entry in its column.

If a matrix satisfies these properties, then the matrix is said to be in reduced row echelon form. The process of Gaussian elimination is in general the fastest way to solve larger systems of equations as it is easily generalised to matrices of larger sizes.

In summary, this means that in order to solve a system of linear equations we do the following:

  1. Put the system of linear equations in the form \(A \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}\) where \(A\) is the matrix of coefficients, \(\mathbf{x}\) is the column vector of variables, and \(\mathbf{b}\) is the column vector of the values of the rhs of each equals sign.
  2. Form the augmented matrix of the system by appending the vector \(\mathbf{b}\) to the right hand side of the matrix \(A\).
  3. Perform Gaussian elimination on the augmented matrix until it is in reduced row echelon form.
  4. Read off the solutions of the system of equations.
